captions.text:
Mario &amp; Luigi: Brothership
is the latest Mario RPG.

Not to be confused with Super
Mario RPG; that was on the SNES.

The Mario &amp; Luigi continuity began
with Superstar Saga in 2003 and consists

of Partners in Time, Bowser&#39;s Inside
Story, Dream Team, and Paper Jam,
the latter being a one-time crossover

with the separate Paper
Mario continuity of Mario RPGs,

consisting of Paper Mario,
Thousand-Year Door,

Super Paper Mario, Sticker Star,
Color Splash, and Origami King.
Got all that?
Yes, the RPGs

have become a particularly gnarled
and twisted branch of the Mario tree,

not one you&#39;d want to attach a swing
to unless you really hate your kids

and secretly hope they
hang themselves.

Brothership is the first Mario
&amp; Luigi game on the Switch

and also the first to be
developed by Acquire Corp

after the developers of previous Mario &amp;
Luigi games, Alpha Dream, went defunct.
Still with me?
Well, we&#39;re not done.

Now I have to try to briefly summarize
the established backstory of the Mario

&amp; Luigi games that you need
to know going into Brothership.
Ready?

Mario and Luigi are two
funny Italian brothers.
Oh. Well, that part was easy.

Surprising amount of mileage
in the concept, really.

Man, if you woke up
someone who&#39;d been in a coma

for 50 years and showed
them the Mario Brothers

and the Domino&#39;s logo
and asked them to identify

which was a pizza company and
which was a gaming franchise,
you&#39;d probably blow their fucking minds.

Brothership opens with Mario and Luigi
getting teleported to a fantastic world
of adventure. It&#39;s that sudden.

They&#39;re literally just
going about their day

when the universe goes,
&quot;Oh, shit. The game&#39;s starting.

Bam. Portal to fantastic
world of adventure.
Remember to roll as you land!&quot;

The world of adventure in question
consists of a society of—okay,

you know how a lot of
non-tentpole Nintendo games

feel like they got their theming
from a designer bereft of ideas

glancing around at the objects
on their workstation,

and that&#39;s how we got shit like
Sticker Star and Kirby&#39;s Epic Yarn?

Well, apparently for
Brothership, their gaze

finally went off the crafting desk
and fell upon the nearby wall
because the Mario brothers

find themselves tasked to save a race
of sentient electrical outlet people.

I know it sounds like I&#39;m taking the
piss, but that&#39;s what they are.

Ever since Origami King
unironically had a hole punch

as a boss fight, the line between reality
and pisstake has only gotten blurrier.

Probably because of all the piss on it.
Anyway, the homeland of the outlet people

has been broken up into a
bunch of floating islands,

and our job is to reunite them by
visiting each one and attaching them

to the titular Brothership
via extension cord.

There&#39;s this overarching
theme of reunification

that&#39;s more on the nose than a
blackhead strip because the

electrical cable-themed bad guys literally
have a gun that makes people antisocial,

but I don&#39;t think this is teaching our
kids the right lesson about not plugging

too many splitters into a
single electrical socket.

So, you should know what to expect
if you&#39;ve played a previous

Mario &amp; Luigi adventure—control M and L as
they form the world&#39;s smallest conga line;

solve platforming puzzles;
get into turn-based battles

that need more contextual button
prompts than an absent-minded tailor.

But it soon became clear
that beyond the superficial,

Brothership feels distinctly
different to its predecessors.

For one thing, the characters
are now 3D modelled,

and despite a manful effort to recreate
the previous sprite animations in 3D,

the characters have lost
a certain expressiveness.
And I&#39;m a little weirded out by the fact

that they added jiggle physics to
Mario&#39;s tight little Mediterranean booty.

There&#39;s also been some changes
to the core gameplay in that

you have less direct control of Luigi; where
previously he only jumped when instructed,

now he takes the initiative more
often to keep up with his brother,
which makes platforming easier

most of the time but harder
when exactitude is called for,

so it&#39;s more a lateral change
than an improvement,

like shifting to the other buttock
halfway through a dull meeting.

The other major new gameplay mechanic
is that you unlock special plugs
that give you advantages in combat,

like extra damage to flying enemies
or ones wearing blue underpants,

sort of like the badge system from Paper
Mario but where they run out of juice

and need time to recharge so
you&#39;re incentivised to experiment,
and with a metaphorical surge protector

interface to help sugarcoat
the fact that the Mario Brothers

probably have to stick these
things up their bumholes.

But it does very little to
help what&#39;s always been

the legacy problem with
Mario and Luigi combat,

and that&#39;s that it takes
way too bloody long.

Mario and Luigi looked at that nice,
elegant system from Paper Mario

and Super Mario RPG—press the
button right when the attack lands

to do extra damage—and thought, “Hey,
if we added 19 more button presses,
our combat will be 19 times as elegant!”

So brush lightly against one fucking Goomba,
and you spend the next five minutes

locked into a fight with
nine of the buggers, playing

keepy-uppy with Koopa
shells for eight button presses

and getting kicked in the spaghetti
and meatballs if you miss a single one.
Why go through all the trouble

of recreating the prolonged Bros
attacks from previous games in 3D

and not take the opportunity
to improve them?
It&#39;s like laundering your underpants

and then carefully reapplying
all the cum stains.

I suppose on that note, the main overarching
issue with Brothership is that it mostly

feels like going through motions
we&#39;ve motioned many times before.

The plot, for example, features a
new original support NPC who&#39;s always

banging on about their beloved mentor
who mysteriously vanished, and meanwhile,

there&#39;s a new main villain who occasionally seems
confused about things and wears a big collar

and hat that hides their identity
when viewed from behind,

and I&#39;m like, “Bitch, even if this wasn&#39;t the
exact same twist from Super Paper Mario,

it&#39;s still the kind of twist
you could predict

from looking at the screenshots
at the back of the box.”
The box, children.

It&#39;s a sort of hard, plastic wallet
thing they used to sell games in.

The system for navigating the
map on the titular Brothership

by switching to currents
is new to the franchise

but is also the exact midpoint
between the map traversal methods

from Zelda: Phantom Hourglass
and Zelda: Spirit Tracks.

Having to wait for the ship
to get to destinations

so you&#39;ve got free time to pursue
sidequests and the like is something

I&#39;d normally appreciate
in a game like this,

but not when the sidequests
are all really bloody boring.
Wait a minute.
I think I&#39;ve just had an epiphany.

It&#39;s so clear now. That&#39;s why
playing the game felt like a chore.

That&#39;s why I started skipping sidequests
and hurrying through the critical path.

It&#39;s because...it&#39;s a really
bloody boring game.

With too much prolonged samey combat,
little variance in the environments,

and the tell-tale stretch
marks of needless padding.

I mean, when you get to the fourth
sea, the game goes, &quot;Oh no!

Two of the islands you&#39;ve
already collected broke off!&quot;

And you just have to hook them up again.
Through exactly the same method as before.

Which certainly does smack
of a game desperately

thinking about baseball to sustain
itself for a few more thrusts.
Guess we&#39;ll leave it there, then.
Really bloody boring; don&#39;t recommend.
Aggregate that, Metacritic.
